content: The Neolithic period begins in Tamil Nadu, with evidence of early settlements in the Kaveri River Valley and megalithic burial sites.
The Sangam period begins, marking the classical age of Tamil literature, arts, and culture with the establishment of the Tamil Sangams.
The Chola dynasty emerges as a major power, establishing trade links with Rome and Southeast Asia from ports like Poompuhar.
The Pallava dynasty establishes its capital at Kanchipuram, initiating a golden age of temple architecture and Sanskrit learning.
Construction of the Mahabalipuram shore temples begins under Pallava rule, showcasing Dravidian architecture.
The Medieval Chola Empire rises under Vijayalaya Chola, beginning their most powerful period in South Indian history.
The Brihadeeswarar Temple in Thanjavur is completed under Raja Raja Chola I, demonstrating the peak of Chola architecture.
The Pandya dynasty becomes dominant after the decline of the Cholas, ruling from Madurai.
The Vijayanagara Empire extends its control over Tamil Nadu, bringing a new era of cultural synthesis.
The Nayak dynasty establishes control over various regions of Tamil Nadu, contributing to art and architecture.
The British East India Company establishes Fort St. George in Madras (Chennai), marking the beginning of British presence.
Most of Tamil Nadu comes under direct British rule as part of the Madras Presidency.
The Justice Party is formed, initiating the Dravidian Movement that would shape Tamil Nadu's politics.
E.V. Ramasamy (Periyar) launches the Self-Respect Movement, promoting social reform and Tamil identity.
India gains independence, with Madras State becoming part of the Indian Union.
The state is reorganized based on linguistic lines, forming the Tamil-speaking Madras State.
DMK comes to power, marking the beginning of Dravidian party rule in Tamil Nadu that continues to present.
Madras State is renamed Tamil Nadu, reflecting its Tamil linguistic and cultural identity.
Tamil Nadu emerges as a major industrial hub with the establishment of numerous automotive and technology industries.
The Indian Ocean tsunami severely impacts Tamil Nadu's coastal regions, leading to major rehabilitation efforts.
Chennai experiences severe floods, highlighting urban infrastructure challenges and climate change impacts.
Jallikattu protests in Chennai lead to changes in laws regarding traditional cultural practices.
